```{r}
pacman::p_load(pacman,tidyverse,lubridate,tidymodels,modeltime, seasonal)

h <- read_csv('~/HOUSTNSA.csv')
h$month <- lubridate::month(h$DATE)

h_sample <- h %>%
  filter(DATE >= "1960-01-01" & DATE <= "2021-12-31")
head(h_sample)
```

```{r}
h_sample$spring <- ifelse((h_sample$month == 3|h_sample$month == 4|h_sample$month == 5),1,0)
h_sample$summer <- ifelse((h_sample$month == 6|h_sample$month == 7|h_sample$month == 8),1,0)
h_sample$fall <- ifelse((h_sample$month == 9|h_sample$month == 10|h_sample$month == 11),1,0)
h_sample$winter <- ifelse((h_sample$month == 12|h_sample$month == 1|h_sample$month == 2),1,0)
```

```{r}
# Appropriately regress the housing start series on these dummy variables, using the sample period from Jan 1960 - Dec 2021

h_sample <- h_sample %>%
  select(-month)

fit1 <- lm(HOUSTNSA ~ ., h_sample) #winter comes in as NA. Because of exact colinearity?

summary(fit1)

fit1$coefficients
```

```{r}
#Present the estimated coefficients from that regression, and plot a time series graph that includes the actual data superimposed on the (smoothed) seasonally adjusted series from the regression.

houstnsa_co <- data.frame(fit1$coefficients) #Why is winter showing as NA? Exact colinearity?

h_sample %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=DATE,y=HOUSTNSA))+
  geom_line()
```
